metadata.title: Building a frontend for a Raspberry Pi Machine Learning Server with Intel Movidius NCS | by Alexey Györi | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Building a frontend for a Raspberry Pi Machine Learning Server with Intel Movidius NCS
metadata.description: This is part of a series on CV applications for the RaspberryPi. Make sure to also check out part 1 on Deploying Intel OpenVino on the PI.

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Https is necessary since modern browser enforce it for accessing webcam feeds

all_paragraphs: This is part 2 of a series on Computer Vision (CV) applications for the RaspberryPi and the Intel Movidius Neural Compute Stick 2 (NCS)¹. Check out part 1 on running object recognition with OpenVino.

· QUICKSTART / TL;DR· Motivation· Requirements· 0. Overview· 1. Machine Learning Model· 2 Setting up a Flask Backend and Webserver· 3. Writing the JavaScript frontend· 4. Starting the server· 5. Results· Footnotes
Set up OpenVino2020_4² with an Intel Neural Compute Stick 2 on your raspberry pi and clone this Github repository onto it.
Verify that everything is set up correctly via
You can now navigate to your pi via typing https://raspberrypi.local:5000³ into a browser. The application is configured to detect pedestrians from the back camera of your phone or laptop camera.

Intel’s OpenVino toolkit makes it easy to deploy ML models from a large model zoo. It even includes a python demo for object classification which uses asynchronous processing. However, when using just the given pure-python demo for any video processing, you need to
A. physically attach the camera to the pi
B. do the video feed rendering on the pi which offloads additional load onto its limited CPU.

Instead, to offset these shortcomings, we run the model inside a flask server and offload any video capturing and rendering operation onto the client. This makes real-time high framerate applications possible with relatively low energy consumption. Also, the Pi can act as a kind of persistent storage for all of your detections.
One example application of this could be to create a security camera from an old Android phone.
We will be using a pre-trained neural network from the OpenVino model zoo which will detect whether there is a pedestrian or not in the current camera feed.

It is important to note that models are OpenVino version dependent. I.e., you cannot run a 2019_R1.1 model on OpenVino 2021.1 (see ²). Hence, the link below will be different depending on which version of OpenVino you installed. To download other versions go to the root https://download.01.org/opencv/ dir, select your version of the toolkit and go to open_model_zoo/. Use the FP16 version⁴
create a new file called model.py which is going to do the inference.

The set_up_inference() function that we just wrote will initialize our neural network for further use and return a net object . Note that OpenVino ships with a modified version of OpenCV which contains additional APIs for working with OpenVino models.
Let’s add a recognize method which will perform the inference⁶ and will return the bounding-box coordinates of detections.
You can download the full model.py file here
To test that the detection produces the expected results in order to sanity check that everything is set up correctly, let’s write a test⁷.
Firstly, let’s add two images of test data. One with just a person’s face and one with a full body.
Since we are using the pedestrian detection model, we would expect that the face is NOT recognized while the person standing on the mountain IS recognized. Create a file test_detecting.py
You can run the test via executing python3 -m unittest .
This concludes the work on our model 🎉.
Here, we are going to 1. write a process function which will process images sent to it via the /upload route:
There are three routes defined here:
We are done with the backend 💖 , for now; starting the server will be handled in 4.
Create a static folder and an images output folder, cd into it and download webcam.js. Webcam.js⁸ is a helper library for capturing the webcam feed.
now let’s write index.html and firstly create a skeleton which will contain our detecting function:
let’s now look into our main snapshotting function. Add the following code right below line 32:
the take_snapshot function does the snapshot taking and posting the picture to the backend. If the backend responds successfully (code 200)

Since this function is executed asynchronously to the video rendering on your screen, any video feed being processed can run at the maximum possible fps of the camera (e.g., 30 or 60) and the video feed appears smooth with no lag.
3.2 serve all images from the output folder
Additionally, we would like to be able to see all images that had a detection in a collection. Create the file templates/images.html:

Note that the for loop here is NOT JavaScript. Instead, we are using Flask’s Jinja2 templating engine to pass all filenames in the folder static/images via os.listdir() (see the index.html on top for the code). Flask will dynamically generate HTML code based on the input to display all images¹⁰ that will look like this:
You can start the server with the following bash script:
— without-threads makes sure that the flask server does not start multiple threads for processing. This is not strictly necessary but makes sure that we do not
— FLASK_APP sets the file to run as main.py

— cert ad-hoc gives us an https certificate. Https is necessary since modern browser enforce it for accessing webcam feeds. Unfortunately there will be an ugly warning in your browser⁵ which you can safely ignore (click on I trust the risks... )¹¹
That’s it, we are done 😎

Open https://raspberrypi.com:5000 and ignore the https warning. The model will start detecting after five seconds and will save all images with detections. Open the detections via clicking on the button on the top left.
The resulting service is able to show you the webcam feed fluently at 30fps on any device while doing bounding-box predictions on the pi.
There are a lot of places you could go now. Some ideas:
Did you like this article and want to try something similar on your Christmas break? Post it in the comments. I’d love to hear about other projects in this space.
Software Engineer at Google in AMS. Previously at Uber, Spotify and in research at FIR@RWTH Aachen. Opinions are my own.
